revision.text:
'''Abd Rabbo''' ({{lang-ar| عبد ربه }} is a male Arabic given name and surname. Notable bearers of the name include:
*[[Ibn ʿAbd Rabbih]] (860–940), Moorish writer and poet *[[Yasser Abed Rabbo]] (born 1944), Palestinian politician *[[Abd Rabbuh Mansur Al-Hadi]] (born 1945), Yemeni politician, President of Yemen *[[Abed Rabah]] (born 1975), Israeli footballer *[[Hosny Abd Rabo]] (born 1984), Egyptian footballer
==See also== *[[Abd Rabbo family incident]], violent incident in 2009
{{given name}}
[[Category:Arabic masculine given names]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2015}} {{Infobox person | name = AbdelRahman Mansour
{{lang|ar| عبد الرحمن منصور}} | image_size = | alt = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1987}} | birth_place = [[Mansoura, Egypt]] | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | body_discovered = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | residence = [[Cairo]], [[Egypt]] | nationality = [[Egypt]]ian | other_names = | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = [[Mansoura University]] ([[Bachelor of Arts]], Journalism Dept.) | occupation =Visiting Scholar, College of Education | years_active = 2009–present | employer =University of Illinois | home_town = | criminal_charge = | criminal_penalty = | criminal_status = | spouse = | partner = | children = | website = | footnotes = |image =}} '''AbdelRahman Mansour''' ({{lang-ar|عبد الرحمن منصور}}; born in 1987) is an Internet activist, journalist and human rights defender. In 2011, he came up with the idea of turning Egypt's National Police Day on 25 January into a Facebook event, "Revolution of the Egyptian People," sparking the online campaign for pro-democracy demonstrations that later snowballed into a popular uprising.{{Cite web|url=http://www.jadaliyya.com/pages/index/9772/meet-abdelrahman-mansour-who-made-25-january-a-dat|title=Jadaliyya|last=جدلية|first=Jadaliyya -|website=Jadaliyya - جدلية|language=en|access-date=2017-12-05}} About to start his compulsory military service in early January 2011, just before [[25 January revolution]], Mansour remained anonymous without announcing his role as the underground Cairo-based administrator of the Facebook page "We are all Khaled Saeed", the main online tool that mobilized the initial mass protests against torture and [[police brutality]], and which culminated weeks later in the ouster of Egyptian strongman [[Hosni Mubarak]], who had ruled the country for the previous three decades.https://www.reuters.com/article/us-egypt-revolution-idUSTRE73C18E20110413 [[Wael Ghonim]], who was living abroad at the time, was the page's publicly known administrator. == Background== Abdelrahman was born to a middle-class family in 1987 in Mansoura, Egypt. He earned a Bachelor of Arts in [[Journalism]] and [[Broadcasting]] from [[Mansoura University]] in 2010. After his graduation and immediate conscription, he traveled to the United States in late 2013 to continue his academic studies. == Career == He first became politically active in 2005, joining the protest movement [[Kefaya]] to demand political reforms in Egypt, and later participated in student movements across several Egyptian universities. Since then, he has been active in raising awareness among Arab audiences on the importance of political activism, citizen movements and broadcasting {{Cite news|url=https://global.ilmanifesto.it/abdelrahman-mansour-the-people-will-do-to-el-sisi-what-they-did-to-mubarak/|title=Abdelrahman Mansour: ‘the people will do to el-Sisi what they did to Mubarak’|date=2016-07-06|work=Il manifesto global|access-date=2017-12-05|language=en-GB}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2012/11/19/eyewitness-in-gaza-an-egyptian-risks-death-beside-the-palestinians|title=Eyewitness in Gaza: An Egyptian Risks Death Beside the Palestinians|last=Topol|first=Sarah A.|date=2012-11-20|work=The Daily Beast|access-date=2017-12-05}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2016/01/arab-spring-egypt-silent-protest-160124101244868.html|title=My Arab Spring: Egypt's silent protest|website=www.aljazeera.com|access-date=2017-12-05}} Abdelrahman became an active blogger with “Kulina Layla (We are all Layla),” a feminist initiative that provided Arab women with an electronic platform to counter conservative voices in mainstream social media. He worked to expand the platform, introducing it in Morocco and Saudi Arabia.{{Cite web|url=http://www.jadaliyya.com/pages/index/9772/meet-abdelrahman-mansour-who-m|title=Jadaliyya|last=جدلية|first=Jadaliyya -|website=Jadaliyya - جدلية|language=en|access-date=2017-12-05}} In 2009, he began collaborating with Wael Ghonim to moderate and manage the online page of [[Mohamed ElBaradei|Mohamed Elbaradei]], who had returned to Egypt the same year. After the tragic death of Khalid Saeed, the two online activists started the Facebook page "We Are All Khaled Saeed". ==Involvement in the Egyptian Revolution of 2011== In 2010, Abdelrahman and Wael Ghonim founded the Facebook page, "We Are All Khaled Saeed," to commemorate the death of Khaled Saeed, a young Egyptian who was tortured to death by police in Alexandria in the same year. They utilized the page, with up to 3,000,000 followers, to mobilize for anti-government and anti-torture protests on 25 January. On 14 January, Abdelrahman conducted a survey on the page to test the waters, asking members if they would follow in the footsteps of Tunisians and take to the streets on 25 January. Enough enthusiasm poured prompting him and Wael to generate an online event entitled: 25 يناير ثورة على التعذيب والفساد والظلم والبطالة (January 25: Revolution against Torture, Corruption, Unemployment and Injustice). This first call to protests was soon picked up by many other activists. Both Abdelrahman and Wael collaborated anonymously with other activists on-the-ground to plan the locations for the protests. The page was also influential in organizing innovative activities such as the Silent Stands and the Police Communication Campaign.{{cite web|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/110524/20110209/wael-ghonim-google-marketing-executive-egypt-protests-detained-released-face-protestors-facebook-twi.htm |title=Google man Wael Ghonim emerges as the face of Egypt protests - International Business Times |publisher=Ibtimes.com |date=2011-02-09 |accessdate=2011-07-08}}{{cite web|url=http://anarchitext.wordpress.com/2011/03/27/wael-ghonim/ |title=Wael Ghonim " AnarchitexT |publisher=Anarchitext.wordpress.com |date=2011-03-27 |accessdate=2011-07-08}} In the aftermath of the Arab Spring uprising in Egypt, Abdelrahman criticized the country's Islamists for their misrule; mainly "marginalizing other political forces" and sidelining youth groups.https://www.reuters.com/article/us-arabs-uprisings-idUSBRE91D0S620130214 He also criticized young activists, or revolutionaries, for their lack of political engagement and failing to develop a political platform that builds on their protest demands.{{Cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/sara-khorshid/the-egyptian-revolutionar_b_6684882.html|title=The Egyptian Revolutionaries: What Went Wrong|last=Khorshid|first=Sara|date=2015-02-17|website=Huffington Post|language=en-US|access-date=2017-12-05}} == See also == {{portal|Egypt|Google|Human rights}} * [[Wael Ghonim]] * [[April 6 Youth Movement]] * [[Asmaa Mahfouz]] * [[Death of Khaled Mohamed Saeed]] * [[Wael Abbas]] * [[George Ishak]] * [[Ahmed Ghanem]] * [[Mohamed Soliman]] * [[Hossam el-Hamalawy]] ==References== == External links == {{Facebook|ghonim}} * [http://today.almasryalyoum.com/article2.aspx?ArticleID=492114&IssueID=3851 AbdelRahman Mansour speaks in the 5th anniversary of the January 25 revolution] * {{Aljazeeratopic|person/wael-ghonim}} * {{NYTtopic|people/g/wael_ghonim}} * [https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12400529 Profile: Egypt's Wael Ghonim], [[BBC News]], 8 February 2011 * Wael, one of "TIME 100" people 2011: [http://globalspin.blogs.time.com/2011/04/27/wael-ghonim-at-the-time-100-gala/ 5min speech at the gala], and: [http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,2066367_2066369_2066437,00.html honoured from M.ElBaradei and short statement] {{Egyptian Revolution of 2011}} {{Arab Spring}} {{Egypt topics}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Mansour, AbdelRahman}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1986 births]] [[Category:Mansoura University alumni]] [[Category:People from Cairo]] [[Category:People of the Egyptian revolution of 2011]] [[Category:Internet activists]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2018}} {{EngvarB|date=February 2018}} '''Alan Hodge''' (16 October 1915 – 25 May 1979) was an English historian and journalist. He was a member of the circle of writers and artists that centred around [[Laura Riding]] and [[Robert Graves]] in the late 1930s, and later collaborated with Graves on ''[[The Long Week-End]]'', a social history of Britain between the wars, and ''The Reader Over Your Shoulder'', a guide to writing English prose. After the Second World War he worked as the general editor of [[Hamish Hamilton]]'s Novel Library, as an editorial assistant on [[Winston Churchill]]'s ''[[A History of the English-Speaking Peoples|History of the English-Speaking Peoples]]'', and as a founding co-editor (with [[Peter Quennell]]) of the successful magazine ''[[History Today]]''.
== Parentage and education ==
Alan Hodge was born on 16 October 1915 in [[Scarborough, North Yorkshire|Scarborough]], Yorkshire; his father was T. S. Hodge, a [[Cunard Line]] captain and officer in the [[Royal Naval Reserve]]. He grew up in [[Liverpool]] and attended [[Liverpool Collegiate School]] before going up to [[Oriel College, Oxford]] where he read history.{{sfn|Anonymous|1981|p=373}}<ref>{{cite book |last1=Watt |first1=Homer Andrew |last2=Cargill |first2=Andrew |year=1948 |title=College Reader |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=ILUVAQAAMAAJ&q=%22Born+in+Scarborough,+on+the+Yorkshire+coast+of%22&dq=%22Born+in+Scarborough,+on+the+Yorkshire+coast+of%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjIq5GXq-zYAhWCI1AKHU5KDh8Q6AEIKTAA |location=New York |publisher=Prentice-Hall |page=929 |access-date=12 February 2018 }}</ref>{{sfn|Quennell|1980|p=157}} In his spare time he wrote poetry and, with [[Kenneth Allott]], co-edited the Oxford University English Club's magazine, ''Programme''.{{sfn|Anonymous|1979}}<ref>{{cite web |url=http://copac.jisc.ac.uk/id/42221030?style=html&title=Programme.No.%2013%20(February%205%2C%201936) |title=Catalogue entry |author=<!--Not stated--> |date=n.d. |website=Copac |access-date=12 February 2018 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://copac.jisc.ac.uk/id/42508424?style=html&title=Programme.No.%2016%20(May%206%2C%201936) |title=Catalogue entry |author=<!--Not stated--> |date=n.d. |website=Copac |access-date=12 February 2018}}</ref>
== The Riding-Graves circle ==
In 1935 Hodge, then in his second year at Oriel, wrote a review of the first volume of ''Epilogue'', an irregular critical journal, which led to a correspondence with its editor, the American poet [[Laura Riding]]. Riding invited Hodge to visit her at the house in [[Majorca]] she shared with [[Robert Graves]], and Hodge duly turned up in time for Christmas.{{sfn|Baker|1993|p=331}}{{sfn|Seymour-Smith|1982|p=260}} He made an excellent impression; Graves noted in his diary, "Hodge very decent & sensible", and described him as "young, blonde good head".{{sfn|Seymour-Smith|1982|pp=260–261}} Another description of his appearance a year or so later described him as "a small blond boy with a cherubic soprano's face, an incongruously deep and hollow voice, and a deliberate, sententious manner; he seemed about sixteen".<ref>{{cite book |last1=Matthews |first1=T. S. |year=1979 |orig-year=1977 |title=Under the Influence |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=7yQrAAAAMAAJ&q=%22incongruously+deep+and%22&dq=%22incongruously+deep+and%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiJssOb-aDZAhUP3qQKHfTQDlc4ChDoAQg6MAM |location=London |publisher=Cassell |pages=153–154 |isbn=0304304085 |access-date=12 February 2018 }}</ref> Hodge went home in early January 1936, but returned the following July to spend the summer holidays there. He was kept busy helping with a planned series of schoolbooks, contributing to ''Epilogue'', and writing poems.{{sfn|Seymour-Smith|1982|p=261}}{{sfn|Seymour|1996|p=239}}{{sfn|Graves|1990|p=270}} During July the [[Spanish Civil War]] broke out, and on 2 August, acting on official advice, the entire household left Majorca aboard a British destroyer.{{sfn|Seymour-Smith|1982|pp=263–264}} Hodge settled in London with his new girlfriend Beryl Pritchard, a [[Philosophy, Politics and Economics|PPE]] student he had met at Oxford, but remained a part of the circle of writers and artists dominated by Laura Riding.{{sfn|Baker|1993|p=368}}{{sfn|Seymour|1996|p=258}} Before long he decided to return to Spain to work for the beleaguered [[Second Spanish Republic|Socialist government]], despite himself being a lifelong Conservative, but Riding told him he must stay in England. Hodge, who was becoming her closest disciple, acquiesced.{{sfn|Baker|1993|p=369}}{{sfn|Graves|1990|p=275}}{{sfn|Seymour-Smith|1992|p=313}} At this time he was working on a novel called ''A Year of Damage'', based on his experiences with a former girlfriend, [[Audrey Beecham]], and by the spring of 1937 it was completed. Graves and Riding supervised its progress closely and made many suggestions for its improvement, all of which he adopted, but though both of them loved the finished book Hodge wouldn't publish it, and destroyed the manuscript.{{sfn|Seymour-Smith|1992|pp=277, 287}}{{sfn|Seymour|1996|p=254}} In the second half of 1937 he used his skills as a historical researcher to help Graves with the writing of ''[[Count Belisarius]]'', a novel set in the [[Byzantine Empire under the Justinian dynasty|early Byzantine Empire]];{{sfn|Graves|1991|p=281}} and at about the same time they worked on a historical survey of the influence of politics on literature, eventually published in Harry Kemp <!-- Not [[Harry Kemp]] --> and Laura Riding's book ''The Left Heresy in Literature and Life''.<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=News and Notes |work=The Times Literary Supplement |location=London |date=24 December 1938 |page=809 }}</ref> These were only the first results of a fruitful partnership between the two friends.
== First marriage ==
On 29 January 1938 Hodge and Beryl Pritchard were married. Beryl had previously doubted it was a good idea, but Hodge won her round; Beryl's parents were less amenable, her father being rude to Hodge at the wedding, and her mother telling her she was throwing her life away.{{sfn|Baker|1993|pp=368-369}}{{sfn|Seymour-Smith|1992|p=302}} In June Riding, Graves, the Hodges and two more of the coterie travelled to [[Rennes]] in [[Brittany]] and found a large country house, which they rented and moved into.{{sfn|Seymour|1996|pp=261–262}} A year later the entire party took ship for America, where an old friend of Graves, the journalist [[T. S. Matthews|Tom Matthews]], had engaged to find them a home. The atmosphere in the new community became increasingly claustrophobic and nightmarish as Riding's domination grew more oppressive, and in a few months the group broke up. Hodge, utterly disillusioned with Riding, returned to England with Graves in August, Beryl being expected to follow shortly after. By now the dynamic of the Hodge marriage had completely changed, both coming to suspect that theirs was more a friendship than a romance, while Beryl and Graves had gradually fallen in love with each other.{{sfn|Graves|1991|pp=300–323}}{{sfn|Seymour-Smith|1992|pp=340–341}} On arriving in England Hodge immediately set out on a journalistic assignment to Poland, and was in Warsaw when the German army invaded the country. He managed to return to England by a circuitous journey via Estonia, Finland, Sweden and Norway.{{sfn|Graves|1998|p=6}}{{sfn|Seymour|1996|pp=275–276}} Beryl reached England from America in October and moved in with Graves, a situation which Hodge, after some initial resistance, accepted without ill-feeling. Beryl remained with Graves for the rest of his life, while Hodge kept his close friendship with both.{{sfn|Graves|1991|p=324}}
== Collaborations with Robert Graves ==
Hodge now resumed his literary partnership with Graves, beginning with some historical research on the [[American Revolutionary War|American War of Independence]] for Graves's [[Sergeant Lamb novels]].{{sfn|Graves|p=324}} The next project, ''[[The Long Week-End]]'', was intended as "a reliable record of what took place, of a forgettable sort, during the twenty-one-year interval between the [[World war|two great European wars]]", for which Hodge did research work and wrote first drafts of several of the chapters. The evidence was mainly drawn from [[ephemera]]l sources, such as newspapers, magazines and radio broadcasts, and the book depicted British life in this period as being mainly devoted to frivolities and distractions.{{sfn|Donoghue|1989|p=25}}{{sfn|Seymour|1996|p=285}} ''The Long Week-End'' was completed in June 1940 and published the following November by [[Faber and Faber]], with Graves and Hodge being credited as co-authors. There have been many subsequent editions in Britain and the United States, it has been translated into Danish and Swedish and even published in [[Braille]].{{sfn|Graves||1990|p=295}}{{sfn|Higginson|1966|pp=85–86, 278}}<ref>{{cite web |url=http://copac.jisc.ac.uk/search?&author=alan+hodge&title=long |title=Catalogue search |author=<!--Not stated--> |date=n.d. |website=Copac |access-date=12 February 2018 }}</ref> On its first publication the reaction of academe was mixed. One historian detected the malign influence of the [[Mass-Observation]] movement in the authors' approach, and called it "a strange unfocused photograph of the times, in which, although the 'camera-eye' has not lied, it has failed entirely to introduce any perspective or integration",<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Clark |first1=William D. |date=December 1941 |title=Review of ''The Long Week-End'' |url=http://www.journals.uchicago.edu/doi/abs/10.1086/236582 |journal=The Journal of Modern History |volume=13 |issue=4 |page=563 |access-date=12 February 2018 }}</ref> but the sociologist [[Alfred McClung Lee]] thought it "regrettable that so few books do so well the useful task Graves and Hodge assigned themselves".<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Lee |first1=Alfred McClung |date=December 1941 |title=Review of ''The Long Week-End'' |journal=American Sociological Review |volume=6 |issue=6 |page=923 }}</ref> Press reviews had some very enthusiastic things to say: "thoroughly good reading",<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.kirkusreviews.com/book-reviews/robert-graves2/the-long-week-end/ |title=Review of ''The Long Week-End'' |author=<!--Not stated--> |date=15 June 1941 |website=Kirkus Reviews |publisher=Kirkus Media |access-date=12 February 2018 }}</ref> "swift, ironic, entertaining...fair and penetrating and a thoroughly significant book today",<ref>{{cite news |last=Burt |first=Ruth |date=3 July 1941 |title=Books in Review |url=https://cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=SN19410703.2.27 |work=Sausalito News |access-date=12 February 2018 }}</ref> "it could hardly have been better done".<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Wilson |first1=P. W. |date=1941 |title=Review of ''The Long Week-End'' |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=b4sPAQAAMAAJ&q=%22be+and+it+could+hardly+have+been+better+done%22&dq=%22be+and+it+could+hardly+have+been+better+done%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjItpTflorZAhVBKVAKHbW9CYoQ6AEIKTAA |journal=New York Times Saturday Review of Books and Art |volume=1 |page=9 |access-date=12 February 2018 }}</ref> More recently it has been described as "stimulating and well-informed",<ref>{{cite book |last1=Stratton |first1=Michael |last2=Trinder |first2=Barrie |year=2000 |title=Twentieth Century Industrial Archaeology |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=julHAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA217&dq=%22stimulating+and+well-informed%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjn9sLorKXZAhWNKlAKHYmIAwYQ6AEIOjAD#v=onepage&q=%22stimulating%20and%20well-informed%22&f=false |location=London |publisher=Routledge |page=217 |isbn=0419246800 |access-date=14 February 2018 }}</ref> and by [[Francis Wheen]] as "enthralling",<ref>{{cite news |last=Wheen |first=Francis |date=10 February 2012 |title=Radio at the time of the Queen's accession: forgotten fandangos in my sock drawer |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/the_queens_diamond_jubilee/9074438/Radio-at-the-time-of-the-Queens-accession-forgotten-fandangos-in-my-sock-drawer.html |work=The Telegraph |location=London |access-date=14 February 2018 }}</ref> while for the historian Alfred F. Havighurst "nothing has as yet replaced" it as a social history of the period.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Havighurst |first1=Alfred F. |year=1985 |title=Britain in Transition: The Twentieth Century |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=0Nhq1g1WYmEC&pg=PA658&dq=%22yet+replaced+robert+graves%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj2r8aAkoPZAhXDIlAKHc3-Dq0Q6AEIKTAA#v=onepage&q=%22yet%20replaced%20robert%20graves%22&f=false |edition=4th |location=Chicago |publisher=University of Chicago Press |page=658 |isbn=0226319717 |access-date=14 February 2018 }}</ref>
By August 1940{{sfn|Seymour|1996|p=299}} the two were working together on what Graves called a "new book about English prose...for the general reader, and also for intelligent colleges and [[Sixth form|VI-forms]]".{{sfn|Graves|1998|pp=19–20}} Originally intended to help Graves's daughter Jenny Nicholson, it was eventually published as ''The Reader Over Your Shoulder: A Handbook for Writers of English Prose''.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Graves |first1=William |year=2001 |title=Wild Olives |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=3nQS0Hd2EnsC&pg=PR8&dq=%22wrote+for+my+half-sister%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj5nLnztKXZAhXIY1AKHSRbBTgQ6AEIKTAA#v=onepage&q=%22wrote%20for%20my%20half-sister%22&f=false |location=London |publisher=Pimlico |page=viii |isbn=0712601163 |access-date=14 February 2018 }}</ref> Its plan, which owes something to Riding's 1938 work ''The World and Ourselves'', is as follows:{{sfn|Seymour|1996|p=299}} first come chapters entitled "The Peculiar Qualities of English", "The Present Confusion of English Prose", "Where Is Good English to Be Found?", and "The Use and Abuse of Official English"; then a history of English prose, quoting many examples; then chapters on "The Principles of Clear Statement" and "The Graces of Prose"; finally, taking up the greater part of the book, the authors present under the title "Examinations and Fair Copies" fifty-four stylistically aberrant passages by well-known writers, analyze their faults, and rewrite them in better English. This last section, according to the academic [[Denis Donoghue (academic)|Denis Donoghue]], "accounted for much of the fame and nearly all of the delight that the book has given its readers".{{sfn|Donoghue|1989|p=27}} Getting copyright waivers from each of the 54 writers made demands on the co-authors' time, and since this section was, in Graves's words, "dynamite under so many chairs", also on their diplomacy.{{sfn|Graves|1998|pp=42, 45}} Their private nickname for the book was ''A Short Cut to Unpopularity''.{{sfn|Graves|1990|p=296}} The publishers Faber and Faber initially accepted the book while it was still in progress, but later took fright and dropped it;{{sfn|Graves|1998|pp=24, 36}} it was finally published in May 1943 by [[Jonathan Cape]]. There have been several later editions, some at full length and some drastically abridged.{{sfn|Higginson|1966|pp=92–95}}{{sfn|Donoghue|1989|p=28}} [[G. W. Stonier]], reviewing ''The Reader Over Your Shoulder'' in the ''[[New Statesman|New Statesman and Nation]]'', regretted that "a book, whose general aims are admirable, should be spoilt so often by its pedantry",{{sfn|James|Brown|1944|p=322}} but most other contemporary reviews were favourable: "it might seem that ''The Reader Over Your Shoulder'' would be unavoidably dry on questions of punctuation and grammar, but even here it is witty and stimulating — a desk-book for the writer that should never fail to key him up",<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Munson |first1=Gorham |date=1944 |title=Review of ''The Reader Over Your Shoulder'' |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=5KAGAQAAIAAJ&q=%22dry+on+questions+of+punctuation+and+grammar,+but+even%22&dq=%22dry+on+questions+of+punctuation+and+grammar,+but+even%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwja2NuhvqXZAhWFa1AKHWIECwUQ6AEIKTAA |journal=The Atlantic Monthly |volume=173 |page=125 |access-date=14 February 2018 }}</ref> "a stimulating and stirring book, which meets a great and genuine need of our times", "instructive and entertaining book", "highly pleasurable and in some degree profitable",{{sfn|James|Brown|1944|p=322}} "any editor of [this journal] would mortgage the office filing cabinet to place this book before the eyes of every contributor".<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Bryant |first1=Donald C. |date=1944 |title=Review of ''The Reader Over Your Shoulder'' |journal=Quarterly Journal of Speech |volume=30 |issue=3 |page=354 }}</ref> ''[[The Spectator]]'' wryly noted that "this book, with its high standards, its scholarship and its brilliance, is exactly calculated to suit the contemporary taste for spiced and potted knowledge which it deplores".<ref>{{cite journal |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=1943 |title=Review of ''The Reader Over Your Shoulder'' |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=N53QAAAAMAAJ&q=%22spiced+and+potted+knowledge%22&dq=%22spiced+and+potted+knowledge%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiHjbqX0P3YAhXCalAKHUKVC7IQ6AEILTAB |journal=The Spectator |volume=171 |page=182 |access-date=14 February 2018 }}</ref> [[Evelyn Waugh]] wrote in ''[[The Tablet]]'', "This is the century of the common man; let him write as he speaks and let him speak as he pleases. This the deleterious opinion to which ''The Reader Over Your Shoulder'' provides a welcome corrective"; he ended, "as a result of having read [it]...I have taken about three times as long to write this review as is normal, and still dread committing it to print".<ref>{{cite book |year=1983 |editor1-last=Gallagher |editor1-first=Donat |title=The Essays, Articles and Reviews of Evelyn Waugh |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=nlEeAQAAIAAJ&q=%22still+dread+committing%22&dq=%22still+dread+committing%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiDvqm5_6XZAhUKElAKHeu1AMAQ6AEILzAB |location=London |publisher=Methuen |pages=275–277 |isbn=0413503704 |access-date=14 February 2018 }}</ref> It has been highly praised in the years since. For the sociologist [[C. Wright Mills]] it was "the best book I know" on writing,<ref>{{cite book |last1=Mills |first1=C. Wright |year=2000 |orig-year=1959 |title=The Sociological Imagination |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=UTQ6OkKwszoC&pg=PA219&dq=%22book+I+know+is+Robert+Graves%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjo95eugKbZAhVBbFAKHYSLDDEQ6AEIKTAA#v=onepage&q=%22book%20I%20know%20is%20Robert%20Graves%22&f=false |location=New York |publisher=Oxford University Press |page=219 |isbn=9780195133738 |access-date=14 February 2018 }}</ref> for the academic Greg Myers, "relentlessly [[Linguistic prescription|prescriptive]] and hilarious",<ref>{{cite book |last1=Myers |first1=Greg |year=1996 |chapter=Strategic Vagueness in Academic Writing |editor1-last=Ventola |editor1-first=Eija |editor2-last=Mauranen |editor2-first=Anna |title=Academic Writing: Intercultural and Textual Issues |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=nY-PqP0eJMYC&pg=PA4&dq=%22prescriptive+and+hilarious%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiPvd-ogqbZAhULZFAKHVBpCsIQ6AEIKTAA#v=onepage&q=%22prescriptive%20and%20hilarious%22&f=false |location=Amsterdam |publisher=John Benjamins |page=4 |isbn=9027250537 |access-date=14 February 2018 }}</ref> for the journalist [[Mark Halperin]] "one of the three or four books on usage that deserve a place on the same shelf as [[A Dictionary of Modern English Usage|Fowler]]".<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Halperin |first1=Mark |date=March 1997 |title=A War That Never Ends |journal=The Atlantic Monthly |volume=279 |issue=3 |page=22 }}</ref> The biographer [[Miranda Seymour]] said that "as a handbook to style, it has never been bettered",{{sfn|Seymour|1996|p=299}} and the literary critic Denis Donoghue wrote, "I don't know any other book in which expository prose is read so seriously, carefully, helpfully. For this reason the book is just as important as [[I. A. Richards]]' ''Practical Criticism''". He went on, "there is no point in being scandalized by the assumption in ''The Reader Over Your Shoulder'' that good English is the sort of English written by Graves and Hodge. In my opinion, that claim is justified."{{sfn|Donoghue|1989|pp=27–30}}
By 1941 another project was in the offing alongside ''The Reader Over Your Shoulder''. This was intended as a volume of new poems by Hodge, Graves, [[James Reeves (writer)|James Reeves]], [[Norman Cameron (poet)|Norman Cameron]] and Harry Kemp <!-- Not [[Harry Kemp]] --> , all of whom were veterans of the Laura Riding circle.{{sfn|Graves|1998|p=25}} In the event the publisher, [[Hogarth Press]], rejected Reeves and Kemp from this line-up, so when the book appeared in March 1942 it included 17 poems by Hodge alongside contributions by Graves and Cameron, "published under a single cover for economy and friendship", as the Authors' Note says.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Graves |first1=Robert |year=1997 |editor1-last=Graves |editor1-first=Beryl |editor2-last=Ward |editor2-first=Dunstan |title=Complete Poems. Volume 2 |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=JqJaAAAAMAAJ&q=%22published+under+a+single+cover+for+economy+and+friendship%22+seventeen&dq=%22published+under+a+single+cover+for+economy+and+friendship%22+seventeen&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjfvuSyhabZAhURZFAKHb6YAowQ6AEIKTAA |location=Manchester |publisher=Carcanet |page=322 |isbn=1857542614 |access-date=14 February 2018 }}</ref>{{sfn|Graves|1998|p=35}}{{sfn|Higginson|1966|p=197}} ''[[The Times Literary Supplement]]'' thought Hodge's poems showed "an ironic humour...enriched by a spontaneous vivacity and a sympathetic closeness to nature".<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=Review of ''Work in Hand'' |work=The Times Literary Supplement |location=London |date=11 April 1942 |page=190 }}</ref>
One more book was to have been a collaboration between Graves and Hodge. This was eventually published under Graves's name alone as ''[[The White Goddess|The White Goddess: A Historical Grammar of Poetic Myth]]''. Hodge retired from the project at a fairly early stage, in 1943, as it became clear that this would be a very personal view of the nature of poetic inspiration and would go beyond his own areas of expertise. Of the central thesis of the book Hodge wrote, "I think it is a good myth, that is, it has truth, and it is not necessary to ask whether it is entirely factually true".{{sfn|Graves|1998|pp=70, 7374}} They would not produce another book together again, and Graves began to recede from the foreground of Hodge's life.
== Civil Service and journalism ==
Hodge spent the Second World War at the [[Ministry of Information (United Kingdom)|Ministry of Information]], where he served first under Sir [[Harold Nicolson]],<ref>{{cite book |last1=Graves |first1=Robert |last2=Hodge |first2=Alan |year=1971 |title=The Long Week-End |location=Harmondsworth |publisher=Penguin |page=[1] |isbn=0140032304 }}</ref> then as [[Private Secretary#United Kingdom|Assistant Private Secretary]] to his successor, [[Brendan Bracken]].<ref>{{cite book |year=1980 |editor1-last=Young |editor1-first=Kenneth |title=The Diaries of Sir Robert Bruce Lockhart. Volume 2: 1939–1965 |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=NpQDAAAAMAAJ&q=%22Alan+Hodge%22+1979+1915&dq=%22Alan+Hodge%22+1979+1915&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjxpuO-7d_YAhVNUlAKHVdlDLQQ6AEIPjAE |location=London |publisher=Macmillan |page=167 |isbn=0333184807 |access-date=14 February 2018 }}</ref> In 1944 he added to his workload by taking a job as book-reviewer to the London local paper, the ''[[London Evening Standard|Evening Standard]]''.{{sfn|Graves|1990|p=325}} After the [[United Kingdom general election, 1945|1945 general election]] Bracken was out of office, and Hodge left with him, but when Bracken took on a gossip column called "Men and Matters" at the ''[[Financial Times]]'' in 1946 he appointed Hodge his assistant. According to Hodge's later description of his role as Bracken's literary catalyst he would be "asked to produce a list of targets for attack. Invariably these were shot down by Bracken in withering terms. This was part of a process of warming up by which he got into his stride".<ref>{{cite book |year=1990 |editor1-last=Cockett |editor1-first=Richard |editor1-link=Richard Cockett |title=My Dear Max: The Letters of Brendan Bracken to Lord Beaverbrook, 1925–1958 |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=fXiuAAAAIAAJ&q=%22Bracken+in+withering%22&dq=%22Bracken+in+withering%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwifoe-167nZAhVDYVAKHW3DAc0Q6AEIKTAA |location=London |publisher=Historians' Press |page=16 |isbn=095089009X |access-date=14 February 2018 }}</ref> Not everyone reacted well to this kind of treatment – his civil servants cheered when he departed in 1945, and he is rumoured to have been in some respects the model for [[George Orwell|Orwell]]'s [[Big Brother (Nineteen Eighty-Four)|Big Brother]]{{sfn|Cavendish|2011|p=12}} – but the relationship with Hodge was different, Bracken having a genuine fondness for him as well as a respect for his scholarship.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Quennell |first1=Peter |year=1982 |title=Customs and Characters |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=7FAfAAAAMAAJ&q=%22Brendan+was+fond+of+Alan%22&dq=%22Brendan+was+fond+of+Alan%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjG65Xs67nZAhVBKlAKHRV7AckQ6AEIKTAA |location=London |publisher=Weidenfeld and Nicolson |page=156 |isbn=0297780603 |access-date=22 February 2018 }}</ref>
== Publishing ==
From 1946 to 1952 Hodge worked for the publishing firm [[Hamish Hamilton]] as the general editor of their Novel Library, a series of reprints of classic novels, both English and foreign.{{sfn|Anonymous|1981|p=373}}<ref>{{cite web |url=https://seriesofseries.owu.edu/novel-library/ |title=Novel Library |author=<!--Not stated--> |date=n.d. |website=A Series of Series: 20th Century Publishers Book Series |access-date=16 February 2018 }}</ref> The introductions with which Hodge furnished some of the volumes won the admiration of [[Raymond Chandler]], who wrote to the publisher, "Your man Hodge is a superb editor, the rarest kind of mind...Surely no one could write better introductions".<ref>{{cite book |year=1981 |editor1-last=MacShane |title=Selected Letters of Raymond Chandler |location=London |publisher=Jonathan Cape |pages=202–203 |isbn=0224019627 }}</ref> The series was eventually wrapped up, but Novel Library editions are now much sought after in secondhand bookshops.<ref>{{cite book |last1=James |first1=Clive |author-link1=Clive James |year=2005 |title=The Meaning of Recognition |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=XK9_-XsnCYEC&pg=PA319&dq=%22prettily+handy%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj5zOba_6rZAhWRyKQKHeXYAVsQ6AEIKTAA#v=onepage&q=%22prettily%20handy%22&f=false |location=London |publisher=Picador |page=319 |isbn=0330440284 |access-date=16 February 2018 }}</ref> He also produced for Hamish Hamilton two translations from the French, ''[[Maigret's Mistake]]'' by [[Georges Simenon]] (later reprinted by [[Penguin Books|Penguin]]) and ''Caves of Adventure'' by [[Haroun Tazieff]].<ref>{{cite book |last1=Young |first1=Trudee |year=1976 |title=Georges Simenon: A Checklist of his "Maigret" and Other Mystery Novels and Short Stories in French and in English Translations |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=dfxcAAAAMAAJ&q=%22Hodge+in+Maigret%22&dq=%22Hodge+in+Maigret%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjpzLGzoavZAhUPalAKHZgFBmYQ6AEIKTAA |location=Metuchen, NJ |publisher=Scarecrow Press |page=94 |isbn=0810809648 |access-date=16 February 2018 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=Potholing in the Pyrenees |url=http://find.galegroup.com/ttda/newspaperRetrieve.do?sgHitCountType=None&sort=DateAscend&tabID=T003&prodId=TTDA&resultListType=RESULT_LIST&searchId=R1&searchType=BasicSearchForm&currentPosition=9&qrySerId=Locale%28en%2C%2C%29%3AFQE%3D%28tx%2CNone%2C12%29%22alan+hodge%22%24&retrieveFormat=MULTIPAGE_DOCUMENT&userGroupName=bright&inPS=true&contentSet=LTO&&docId=&docLevel=FASCIMILE&workId=&relevancePageBatch=CS152260869&contentSet=UDVIN&callistoContentSet=UDVIN&docPage=article&hilite=y |work=The Times |location=London |date=5 August 1953 |access-date=16 February 2018 }}</ref>
== Life as a working historian ==
The last 28 years of Hodge's life were dominated by his work on the magazine ''[[History Today]]''. This was the creation of Brendan Bracken, Hodge's old boss and from 1945 Chairman of the Financial News group which owned the ''Financial Times''.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.winstonchurchill.org/publications/finest-hour/finest-hour-113/brendan-bracken-the-fantasist-whose-dreams-came-true/ |title=Brendan Bracken: The Fantasist Whose Dreams Came True |last=Lysaght |first=Charles Edward |date=2001 |website=winstonchurchill.org |publisher=The International Churchill Society |access-date=16 February 2018 }}</ref> One of his projects was the creation of a monthly history magazine to be edited by Hodge, but when in 1950 he decided to act on this plan he brought in the literary biographer [[Peter Quennell]] as well, making the two men co-editors.{{sfn|Quennell|1980|p=157}} Paper-rationing delayed the magazine's launch, but on 12 January 1951 the first issue appeared. ''History Today'' (the title was allegedly suggested by [[Winston Churchill]]) was attractively illustrated and aimed itself at the general reader without writing down to him. The intention, as [[A. L. Rowse]] later wrote, was to "bridge the gap between specialist journals, all too often unreadable by the general public, and the intelligent reader who wanted to read history".<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Rowse |first1=A. L. |date=November 1979 |title=A Tribute to P. Q. and A. H. |url=http://www.historytoday.com/al-rowse/tribute-peter-quennell-and-alan-hodge |journal=History Today |volume=29 |issue=11 |page=701 |access-date=16 February 2018 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Lay |first1=Paul |date=January 2011 |title=From the Editor |url=http://www.historytoday.com/paul-lay/editor-january-2011 |journal=History Today |volume=61 |issue=1 |page=2 |access-date=16 February 2018 }}</ref>{{sfn|Cavendish|2011|p=12}} From the first the magazine brought in a wide range of heavyweight academic historians to contribute articles, the first two issues alone boasting the names of [[G. M. Trevelyan]], [[G. M. Young]], [[Veronica Wedgwood]], [[Eric Linklater]], [[Alan Bullock]], [[A. J. P. Taylor]], [[Denis William Brogan|D. W. Brogan]], [[G. D. H. Cole]] and [[Max Beloff, Baron Beloff|Max Beloff]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.history.ac.uk/makinghistory/resources/articles/history_today.html |title=History Today |last=Furtado |first=Peter |date=2008 |website=Making History |publisher=The Institute of Historical Research |access-date=16 February 2018 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.historytoday.com/jw-bartlett/history-today-and-tomorrow |title=History Today and Tomorrow |last=Bartlett |first=J. W. |date=September 1998 |website=History Today |access-date=16 February 2018 }}</ref> Later Hodge and Quennell brought in experts from a wide range of fields, including [[Kenneth Clark]], [[Freya Stark]], [[Nancy Mitford]], [[Arthur Waley]], [[Julian Huxley]] and [[Michael Grant (classicist)|Michael Grant]].{{sfn|Cavendish|2011|p=12}} Hodge's editorial style was described as "scholarly, imaginative and judicious".{{sfn|Anonymous|1979}}
While editing the magazine Hodge took up a prolonged side-activity, the editing of Winston Churchill's ''[[A History of the English-Speaking Peoples|History of the English-Speaking Peoples]]''. Churchill had begun to work on this massive work during his "wilderness years", in 1932, and it was in [[Galley proof|proof]] by the time he re-entered the Cabinet in September 1939, at which point he had to lay it aside.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Jenkins |first1=Roy |author-link1=Roy Jenkins |year=2002 |orig-year=2001 |title=Churchill |location=London |publisher=Pan |pages=448, 546–547 |isbn=0330488058 }}</ref> In 1953, once again Prime Minister, he returned to the ''History'', uncertain whether it was in a publishable state. His close friend Bracken advised him to take on Hodge as an editorial assistant, the introductions were made, and Hodge soon found himself leading a team of historians advising Churchill on necessary revisions.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Clarke |first1=Peter |author-link1=Peter Clarke (historian) |year=2013 |orig-year=2012 |title=Mr Churchill's Profession |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=xoukhTh_wQgC&pg=PA281&dq=%22Hodge+might+be+able%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjonbyf-63ZAhVRY1AKHY_qD6EQ6AEIKTAA#v=onepage&q=%22Hodge%20might%20be%20able%22&f=false |location=London |publisher=Bloomsbury |page=281 |isbn=9781408831236 |access-date=17 February 2018 }}</ref>{{sfn|Gilbert|1988|p=877}} His brief was to produce "a lively, continuous narrative" emphasizing "famous dramatic events",{{sfn|Gilbert|1988|p=591}} but getting major changes made in the text proved very difficult. "Errors of fact were changed with courteous alacrity," according to the historian [[John H. Plumb]]; "subject to strong pressure, an adjective might or might not be pruned, but the grand design proved immutable."<ref>{{cite book |last1=Plumb |first1=J. H. |year=1988 |title=The Making of an Historian |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=YA8iAQAAIAAJ&q=%22changed+with+courteous+alacrity%22&dq=%22changed+with+courteous+alacrity%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj49fXU0K_ZAhXGZ1AKHWC8B58Q6AEIKTAA |location=Brighton |publisher=Harvester, Wheatsheaf |page=240 |isbn=0710812531 |access-date=18 February 2018 }}</ref> Hodge worked in various places: at home, at the ''History Today'' offices, at [[Chartwell]] (Churchill's home in [[Kent]]), and in the south of France where Churchill spent lengthy holidays. They developed a close friendship, but the work came to an end at last in 1957.{{sfn|Gilbert|1988|pp=1136, 1148, 1163, 1189, 1228–1230}}
One project suffered from Hodge's heavy workload in these years. When his old friend Norman Cameron died from a stroke in 1953 leaving Hodge his copyrights, Hodge agreed to prepare an edition of his poems with an introduction by Robert Graves. This edition hung fire for a long time, to Graves's increasing anger, but the ''Collected Poems'' finally appeared in June 1957.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Graves |first1=Robert |year=1990 |editor1-last=O'Prey |editor1-first=Paul |title=Between Moon and Moon |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=BrnyAAAAMAAJ&q=%22Hodge+had+undertaken+to+prepare%22&dq=%22Hodge+had+undertaken+to+prepare%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjb0fSQ06_ZAhUIJlAKHW0_AYoQ6AEIKTAA |location=Mount Kisco |publisher=Moyer Bell |pages=145, 307 |isbn=1559210311 |accessdate=18 February 2018 }}</ref>{{sfn|Graves|1998|pp=221–222}}
The same year, having resigned as Prime Minister amid heavy press criticism of the [[Suez Crisis]], [[Anthony Eden]] decided to write his memoirs as a way of giving his side of the story. He recruited a team of historians to assist him, and Bracken once more stepped forward to recommend Hodge for his "grace of style and nicety of perspective". Hodge joined the team, and was kept occupied through to 1959.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Moran |first1=Christopher |year=2013 |title=Classified: Secrecy and the State in Modern Britain |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=p24kPDwzXkUC&pg=PA220&dq=%22assembled+a+stellar+research%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjX_O2S1a_ZAhULalAKHX2ZA54Q6AEIKTAA#v=onepage&q=%22assembled%20a%20stellar%20research%22&f=false |location=Cambridge |publisher=Cambridge University Press |page=220 |isbn=9781107000995 |access-date=18 February 2018 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=James |first1=Robert Rhodes |author-link1=Robert Rhodes James |year=1986 |title=Anthony Eden |location=London |publisher=Weidenfeld and Nicolson |page=604 |isbn=0297789899 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |year=1971 |editor1-last=Yates |editor1-first=John V. |title=The Author's and Writer's Who's Who |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=vSUNAAAAIAAJ&q=%22to+sir+anthony+eden+1957+59%22&dq=%22to+sir+anthony+eden+1957+59%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi3rNWS-uvYAhULmbQKHVSeDlwQ6AEIKTAA |edition=6th |location=London |publisher=Burke's Peerage |page=390 |isbn=0850110106 |access-date=18 February 2018 }}</ref>
In 1958 Brendan Bracken died, and Hodge was commissioned to write his biography. He researched his subject diligently,{{sfn|Lysaght|1979|p=15}}{{sfn|PHS|1973}} but found himself hampered by the fact that Bracken had ordered his private papers to be burned after his death and also by a sense of loyalty to his old boss which would not have allowed him to publish everything he found.{{sfn|Lysaght|1979|pp=15, 336}} After several years he abandoned the task and gave his notes to [[Charles Lysaght]] and [[Andrew Boyle]], both of whom were engaged on the same task.{{sfn|PHS|1973}}
In 1960 Hodge and Quennell collaborated on ''The Past We Share: An Illustrated History of the British and American Peoples''.{{sfn|Anonymous|1979}} Reviews were mixed. ''[[Kirkus Reviews]]'' called it "a superb panoramic view of history with a somewhat misleading subtitle, for the emphasis is so largely British that the America aspects take definitely second place", ''[[The New Yorker]]'' "a more than ordinarily serious entry in a frequently trumped-up field",{{sfn|Davison|1962|p=1159}} and ''[[Booklist|The Booklist and Subscription Books Bulletin]]'' "an inviting historical summary for casual reading",;<ref>{{cite journal |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=1960 |title=Review of ''The Past We Share'' |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=3qxTAAAAIAAJ&q=%22illustrations+are+well+placed.+not%22&dq=%22illustrations+are+well+placed.+not%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiO48Oh6K_ZAhUMZlAKHTg4CZ0Q6AEIMTAC |journal=The Booklist and Subscription Books Bulletin |volume=57 |page=350 |access-date=18 February 2018 }}</ref> the ''Times Literary Supplement'' found the illustrations good in themselves but inaccurately captioned,<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=Common Place-Book |work=The Times Literary Supplement |location=London |date=27 January 1961 |page=55 }}</ref> the ''[[New York Herald Tribune]]'' thought that "the real past we share with the English was a broader, harsher, more dynamic and far more astonishing saga of conquest than this genteel survey suggests", ''[[The New York Times]]'' that "the luminous histories of our two peoples have not been dovetailed at all (as the title implied they would be) but rather set side by side to languish augustly in isolation from one another", but the ''[[Chicago Tribune|Chicago Sunday Tribune]]'' believed that "this gallery of a pictured past is as rewarding as any the reader is likely to tour for some time".{{sfn|Davison|1962|p=1159}}
Alan Hodge remained until his death the co-editor with Peter Quennell of ''History Today''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.carcanet.co.uk/cgi-bin/indexer?owner_id=863 |title=Alan Hodge (1915–1979) |author=<!--Not stated--> |date=n.d. |website=Carcanet Press |access-date=18 February 2018 }}</ref> He died at the age of 63 on 25 May 1979.{{sfn|Anonymous|1981|p=373}}
== Personal life ==
In 1942 Hodge opened the way for his first wife, Beryl, to marry Graves by instituting divorce proceedings, and the divorce was made absolute the following year.{{sfn|Seymour|1996|p=287}}{{sfn|Seymour-Smith|1992|p=361}} In the autumn of 1947 he met [[Jane Aiken Hodge|Jane Aiken]], daughter of the poet and novelist [[Conrad Aiken]], and on 3 January 1948 they married.{{sfn|Graves|1998|pp=147–148}} He encouraged her to begin her successful career writing Gothic romances.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://kissandthrill.com/2013/01/22/jane-aiken-hodges-gothic-romances-more-than-just-a-girl-and-her-castle/ |title=Jane Aiken Hodge's Gothic Romances: More than Just a Girl and Her Castle |last=Wray |first=Sharon |date=22 January 2013 |website=Kiss and Thrill |access-date=18 February 2018 }}</ref> They lived in [[Wimbledon, London|Wimbledon]] and later [[Lewes]],<ref>{{cite book |last1=Radcliffe |first1=Elsa J. |year=1979 |title=Gothic Novels of the Twentieth Century: An Annotated Bibliography |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=9Dsx3-Hm7b4C&pg=PA101&dq=%22husband+Alan+Hodge%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj_0df0v7DZAhXQalAKHT7vAV8Q6AEILjAB#v=onepage&q=%22husband%20Alan%20Hodge%22&f=false |location=Metuchen, NJ |publisher=Scarecrow Press |page=101 |isbn=0810811901 |access-date=18 February 2018 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=Forthcoming Marriages |url=http://find.galegroup.com/ttda/newspaperRetrieve.do?sgHitCountType=None&sort=DateAscend&tabID=T003&prodId=TTDA&resultListType=RESULT_LIST&searchId=R1&searchType=BasicSearchForm&currentPosition=71&qrySerId=Locale%28en%2C%2C%29%3AFQE%3D%28tx%2CNone%2C12%29%22alan+hodge%22%24&retrieveFormat=MULTIPAGE_DOCUMENT&userGroupName=bright&inPS=true&contentSet=LTO&&docId=&docLevel=FASCIMILE&workId=&relevancePageBatch=CS236157561&contentSet=UDVIN&callistoContentSet=UDVIN&docPage=article&hilite=y |work=The Times |location=London |date=25 March 1974 |access-date=22 February 2018 }}</ref> and had two daughters, Jessica and Joanna.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Fallon |first1=Eileen |year=1984 |title=Words of Love: A Complete Guide to Romance Fiction |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=kHREAAAAMAAJ&q=%22January+3,+1948;+children:+Jessica+Mary%22&dq=%22January+3,+1948;+children:+Jessica+Mary%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=5rWxU9fxJIPb7AbpxYHgAQ&ved=0CB8Q6AewAA |location=New York |publisher=Garland |page=269 |isbn=9780824092047 |access-date=22 February 2018 }}</ref>
== Books co-authored by Alan Hodge ==
* Robert Graves and Alan Hodge ''[[The Long Week-End|The Long Week-End: A Social History of Great Britain 1918–1939]]'' (London: Faber and Faber, 1940; New York: Macmillan, 1941) * Alan Hodge, Norman Cameron and Robert Graves ''Work in Hand'' (London: The Hogarth Press, 1942) * Robert Graves and Alan Hodge ''The Reader over Your Shoulder: A Handbook for Writers of English Prose'' (London: Jonathan Cape, 1943; New York: Macmillan, 1944){{sfn|Higginson|1966|pp=85–86, 92–93, 197}} * Peter Quennell and Alan Hodge ''The Past We Share: An Illustrated History of the British and American Peoples'' (London: Weidenfeld and Nicolson, 1960; New York: Putnam, 1960)<ref>{{cite book |year=1963 |editor1-last=Rigby |editor1-first=Marjory |editor2-last=Nilon |editor2-first=Charles |title=Annual Bibliography of English Language and Literature. ''[[InfoWars|Infowars.com]]'', devoted to conspiracy theories and [[fake news website|fake news]], and the websites ''[[Alex Jones#NewsWars|NewsWars]]'' and ''[[Alex Jones#PrisonPlanet|PrisonPlanet]]''. Jones has been the center of many controversies, including his promotion of [[Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting conspiracy theories]],{{cite web|first=Timothy|last=Johnson|url=http://mediamatters.org/blog/2016/11/17/trump-ally-alex-jones-doubles-down-sandy-hook-conspiracy-theories/214524 |title=Trump Ally Alex Jones Doubles Down On Sandy Morgan]].{{cite news|first1=Peter|last1=Grier|title=Piers Morgan vs. Alex Jones on gun control: Who won wild debate?|url=https://www.csmonitor.com/USA/Elections/Vox-News/2013/0108/Piers-Morgan-vs.-Alex-Jones-on-gun-control-Who-won-wild-debate|newspaper=[[The Christian Science Monitor]]|publisher=[[Christian Science Publishing Society]]|location=Boston, MA|date=January 8, 2013|accessdate=March 5, 2018}}{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/video/2013/jan/08/alex-jones-pro-gun-tirade-piers-morgan-video|title=Alex Jones' pro-gun tirade at Piers Morgan on British presenter's own show|work=[[The Guardian]]|publisher=[[Guardian Media Group]]|location=London, England|date=January 8, 2013|accessdate=January 10, 2013}} He has accused the U.S. government of planning the [[Oklahoma City bombing]], the [[September 11 attacks]], and has claimed that the [[Moon landing conspiracy theories|moon landing footage was fake]].{{cite web |first=Olivia|last=Nuzzi|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2014/07/29/dear-moon-landing-deniers-sorry-i-called-you-moon-landing-deniers.html |title=Dear Moon Landing Deniers: Sorry I Called You Moon Landing Deniers |work=[[The Daily Beast]] |publisher=[[IAC (company)|IAC]]|location=New York|date=July 29, 2014|accessdate=August 27, 2014 }}{{cite news |first=Christopher|last=Zara|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/alex-jones-blows-bbc-sunday-politics-bilderberg-group-follow-if-my-enemies-murder-me-it-makes-me |title=Alex Jones Blows Up On BBC Sunday Politics For Bilderberg Group Follow-Up: If My Enemies Murder Me, It Makes Me A Martyr |newspaper=[[International Business Times]] |publisher=[[Newsweek Media Group]]|location=New York|date=June 9, 2013 |accessdate=August 31, 2014}}{{cite journal|first=Jeremy|last=Stahl|title=Where Did 9/11 Conspiracies Come From?|url=http://www.slate.com/id/2302830/|magazine=[[Slate
